oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This page in Mitchener's diary from World War II includes a drawing of several POW barracks within the camp. He has written, "An important item on the top of the page. Below is his drawing of the camp, "The Cook Shack." He includes information about the meal, cooking, washing, and baking schedule.

Hardy A. Mitchener, Jr. was captured during World War II after a bombing mission in Germany. He was sent to Stalag Luft III, a POW camp in Silesia (Sagan, Germany), where American and RAF (Royal Air Force) prisoners frequently suffered from hunger, insufficient clothing, and crowded living conditions. Rations were slim, but the prisoners were given Red Cross parcels which provided extra food. The camp cookhouse, run by "combines" (groups of 4-12 POWs) supplied one cooked ration a day, usually barley soup.
